title: Roeland Monasch - Orcanauts Meet Aflatoun, OrcaPod Ep #8

rawLines.text: [Music]
everyone welcome this is ori i'm the
co-founder of orca the most
user-friendly decks on solana and
welcome to our first ever twitter space
today i'm really excited to welcome
roland monash
please tell me if i'm not pronouncing
that correctly roland the ceo of
aflatoon international an organization
that delivers social and financial
education to young people all over the
world welcome to the show hi ori thanks
for having me and greetings from
amsterdam you got my name very well done
perfect i'm really glad you know
sometimes you see the name you're like
i'm just gonna do my best with this one
but yeah we are really really gratified
to have you here with us today
i know our community is really excited
for the launch of orgonauts and a big
reason for that is the fact that orca
will be taking none of the mint revenue
25 goes to the artist uh but the vast
majority that 75 is going to go to the

community the chance to learn a little
bit more about afflatune and the work

want to start just by telling us a
little bit about yourself sure
i'm a specialist on children and
international development
over the past 20 years i've worked for
organizations like unicef world health
organization on issues related to child
health vaccination medical supplies
malaria bad nets distribution
also in the area of education getting
children into school and protection of
the most vulnerable children issues like
child labor teenage pregnancies and
child marriage
during my life we moved around quite a
lot worked in different places like
bhutan pakistan and asia or zambia and
lesotho in africa but also at the united
nations headquarters in new york and
geneva during my last three
international postings i was the unicef
director in zimbabwe i led a large
complex humanitarian operation
in georgia i led the team closing all
the former soviet orphanages and most
recently in sierra leone i let the ebola
response during these years i came to
the realization that there was something
really important missing in in making
children more resilient we were always
resolving problems but
i felt it wasn't a weight and a need to
to empower children to take control of
their own life and
a
in reality in asia africa and many other
places the majority of young people will
not get a job with the corporate sector
or the government they have to start
enterprising themselves
but no one is preparing them for this
and and i really felt it was an urgent
need to empower children with social and
financial skills
uh there is a need to talk with children
and young people about their future and
about money before they drop out of
school so i left the united nations and
joined aflatun five years ago to test
and roll out the concept of
child social and financial education
around the world wow you really have had
quite the career i'm really honored that
we have the chance to partner with
someone who's had the chance to dive so
deep into this this particular mission
since you know we kind of had the the
idea of working on something related to
financial literacy or financial
education but to be honest we didn't

mission was almost exactly what we were

yeah for sure i mean i have a little bit
of background in education in that i
started my career in ed tech but i think
being on the ground
the way that you all have is really

you could tell us a little bit more
about how exactly you define social and
financial education
um and how you defined your mission this
way and and who exactly is your target
audience basically our mission is to
socially and economically empower
children and young people so they become
sort of agents of change in their own
lives but also contribute to the
community for a more equitable world
what we do when we talk about the
concept of social financial education we
take children through a process on sort
of a personal understanding and
exploration who am i what are my dreams
i'm gonna fulfill these dreams and
achieve my dreams
but then embed them in their community
in society so talk about their rights
and responsibilities make them
understand what they can expect from
society but what society also can expect
from them but then we really need to
give them practical tools so we have to
talk about saving responsible spending
how to make a plan and a budget and you
really need those skills in order to to
become successful and and engaged in
your community and and then finally
learning by doing so we we form clubs
with children and young people to set up
social and financial enterprises so in a
nutshell basically we teach children
young people how they can use money to
take care of their lives and make a

communities and we do that through
interactive lesson material we
we work in primary schools secondary
schools universities but also we work
with vulnerable children out of school
dropped out
our target is basically all children in

over 100 countries as you mentioned um
it's from amsterdam to amman from new

the aim is basically to reach every

incredible and it's kind of hard for me
to imagine just the wide range of
different projects that i know that
you've worked on and so i wonder if you
could tell us about one project
specifically that afternoon's worked on
that you personally feel really proud of
yeah it's difficult to choose we have
over 300 projects around the world but
maybe one or two examples in in the

with their local schools and we have an
agreement with
with the department of education and
they are teaching social and financial
education in the schools they're
empowering the teachers and the children
learn about saving and responsible
spending in the school
and through the financial cooperatives
they are also able to open their first

haven't opened an account this way
on the other side is another example in

these young women take control of their

but but to be honest
at the higher level
what i'm most proud of probably is the

education is now becoming an acceptable

when we talked about money and children

financial education was perceived as not
